question: Exertional dyspnoea is typically associated with chronic obstructive airway diseases rather than being the symptomatic hallmark of chronic heart failure.
Examination for the inguinal and popliteal nodes requires the patient to stand upright.
Normal capillary refill time is greater than 10 seconds.
Stroke is a condition where a patient experiences temporary memory loss due to non-vascular causes.
An apical impulse is always easily palpable regardless of body composition or lung health status.

Reversed splitting of S2 ('lub dub' on inspiration; 'lub d-dub' on expiration) occurs when left ventricular emptying is delayed so that the aortic valve closes after the pulmonary valve due to conditions including severe aortic stenosis.

When recording the diastolic pressure during a blood pressure measurement, if muffling sounds persist and do not disappear, the point of muffling is used instead of waiting for complete disappearance of sounds.
Burning retrosternal pain indicates exclusively oesophagitis.
A duplex ultrasound investigation showing deep vein thrombosis necessitates anticoagulant medication.
The ABPI is typically greater than 1.0–1.2 in healthy individuals when they are standing upright.
Finger clubbing is always indicative of lung cancer in adults.
In a correctly performed percussion during a medical examination, a hollow, ringing sound typically indicates air-filled lungs, while a dull thud suggests fluid or consolidation.
Colicky pain typically originates from solid organs rather than hollow structures.
Rectal bleeding may cause complications related to colorectal cancer.
Normal bowel sounds occur every 1–5 seconds.
A hard subcutaneous nodule located at the umbilicus indicates benign growth.
Hippocrates is credited with suggesting that the brain controls various aspects of human behaviour, including movement, emotions, and sensations.
Ensuring both limbs are positioned identically with the same amount of stretch is crucial for accurately comparing reflexes when testing deep tendon reflexes.
A lower motor neuron lesion typically results in increased tone and spasticity.
Cranial nerves originate from brainstem nuclei located throughout the entire human brain.
Damage to the occipital lobe results in disturbances of visual perception including seeing objects smaller than they actually are.
Exposure to manganese results in toxic peripheral neuropathy.
A lumbar puncture always measures the cerebrospinal fluid opening pressure in a sitting position.
The orbicularis oculi muscle, responsible for closing both upper and lower eyelids, is innervated by cranial nerve V.
A cataract may cause glare and usually affects individuals who are young adults.
Cortical parietal lobe lesions always result in significant changes to stereognosis.
When examining a patient's right eye with a direct ophthalmoscope, you should hold the ophthalmoscope in your right hand and use your right eye to examine.
Otalgia associated with pruritus is commonly due to otitis interna.
Diabetic macular edema results in blurred vision due to accumulation of fluid and lipid deposits under the retina, causing significant visual impairment in individuals with diabetes mellitus.

During the Head Impulse Test, if the patient's eyes move with the head when it is turned towards the unaffected side, there is a corrective saccade indicating a deficiency in the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
Otoscopy includes inspecting the external auditory canal and examining the eardrum during the integrated examination sequence for ear, nose, and throat diseases.
The parotid gland is situated behind the ear and has a superficial and deep lobe relative to the facial nerve that does not run through it.
White plaques of candidiasis do not require excision biopsy because they come away easily when scraped.
Prolactin is secreted by the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
Metformin is indicated as first-line pharmacological treatment for type 2 diabetes because it reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis and enhances muscle uptake of glucose.
Primary adrenal insufficiency, commonly referred to as Addison's disease, is primarily due to autoimmune destruction of the adrenal cortex.
More than 75% of the lymphatic drainage of the breast is to the ipsilateral axillary lymph nodes.
Normal ovaries are always easily palpable through bimanual examination regardless of body weight.
Abnormal vaginal bleeding is experienced exclusively by postmenopausal women.
Fetal movements typically start being felt between 16 and 20 weeks’ gestation.
Epididymo-orchitis typically begins with severe acute pain compared to other conditions affecting the male reproductive system.
Normal testicular length is typically less than 4 cm.
Nephrotic syndrome caused by diabetes mellitus results in an increased risk of infection among affected individuals.
